federalContext.law: GENIUS Act (Guiding and Establishing National Innovation for U.S. Stablecoins Act)
federalContext.summary: The GENIUS Act was signed on July 18, 2025 and sets a federal framework for payment stablecoins, including reserve backing, redemptions, supervision, and issuer requirements. Statutory effective date language points to January 18, 2027 (18 months after enactment), with rulemaking-dependent timing in some sections.

pendingFederalBills.title: Digital Asset Market Clarity Act of 2025 (CLARITY Act)
pendingFederalBills.what: Would create a broader federal market-structure framework for digital asset spot markets and regulatory jurisdiction.
pendingFederalBills.status: Passed House; referred to Senate Banking
pendingFederalBills.latest: Latest congressional action (September 18, 2025): received in Senate and referred to Senate Banking. Latest committee scheduling update (January 15, 2026): Senate Banking executive session to consider H.R.3633 was marked POSTPONED (no later committee action listed as of February 17, 2026).

pendingFederalBills.title: Anti-CBDC Surveillance State Act
pendingFederalBills.what: Would limit the Federal Reserve from issuing a U.S. CBDC directly to individuals and from using a CBDC for monetary policy implementation.
pendingFederalBills.latest: Latest action (July 17, 2025): House passed bill, with motion to reconsider laid on the table. No subsequent Senate action is listed in Congress.gov Actions Overview as of February 17, 2026.

pendingFederalBills.title: Digital Asset Tax Reform Bill (Senate)
pendingFederalBills.what: Would establish digital-asset-related federal tax treatment updates, including de minimis treatment discussions and related reporting/tax mechanics.
pendingFederalBills.latest: Latest action (June 30, 2025): introduced in Senate and referred to the Committee on Finance. No newer committee or floor action is listed as of February 17, 2026.

majorStateDevelopments.title: DFAL licensing rollout
majorStateDevelopments.what: California's Digital Financial Assets Law (DFAL) framework and licensing implementation for covered digital-asset activity.
majorStateDevelopments.status: Implementation watch: licensing date remains July 1, 2026.
majorStateDevelopments.latest: DFPI indicates covered persons must obtain a license by July 1, 2026; no later statutory date change is reflected on current DFPI framework pages.

majorStateDevelopments.title: SB 1568 / HB 1415 - Stablecoin Pilot Program
majorStateDevelopments.what: Companion bills would create a Florida Department of Financial Services stablecoin pilot program.
majorStateDevelopments.latest: SB 1568 latest action (February 13, 2026): placed on committee agenda for February 18, 2026 in Senate Appropriations (AEG). HB 1415 latest action (February 13, 2026): 1st Reading (Committee Substitute 1) and referred to Commerce Committee.

majorStateDevelopments.title: SB 2922 - Texas Oil-Backed Stablecoin Act
majorStateDevelopments.what: Would authorize an oil-backed stablecoin framework under Texas law.
majorStateDevelopments.latest: Latest action (April 7, 2025): referred to Senate Business & Commerce; status remains in committee with no newer listed action as of February 16, 2026.

majorStateDevelopments.title: S8901 - CRYPTO Act (unlicensed activity penalties)
majorStateDevelopments.what: Would add criminal penalties for unlicensed virtual currency business activity in New York (Financial Services Law ยง 408-b).
majorStateDevelopments.latest: Latest action (January 14, 2026): introduced and referred to Senate Banks; no later committee vote is listed as of February 17, 2026.

NY.name: New York
NY.summary: New York has one of the strictest crypto regulatory regimes. Most digital asset business activity touching New York or New York residents requires a BitLicense or trust charter, and NYDFS has specific USD-backed stablecoin issuance guidance.
keyLaws: NYDFS Industry Letter on USD-Backed Stablecoins (June 8, 2022)
S8901 (2026) - CRYPTO Act (prohibits unlicensed virtual currency business activity with criminal penalties)
NY.recentDevelopments: New York maintains BitLicense and stablecoin guidance. Separately, S8901 (CRYPTO Act) was introduced on January 14, 2026 and referred to Senate Banks, proposing criminal penalties for unlicensed virtual currency business activity.

timeline.label: BitLicense regime enacted
timeline.detail: New York implemented 23 NYCRR Part 200, creating a dedicated virtual-currency licensing framework.

timeline.label: Stablecoin guidance issued
timeline.detail: NYDFS published guidance for USD-backed stablecoin issuance, including reserve and redemption expectations.

timeline.label: Supervisory updates continue
timeline.detail: NYDFS continued virtual-currency supervision and related policy clarifications impacting stablecoin operations.

timeline.label: CRYPTO Act (S8901) introduced
timeline.detail: S8901 was introduced and referred to Senate Banks; it proposes criminal penalties for unlicensed virtual currency business activity.

NY.regulatoryBody: New York State Department of Financial Services (NYDFS)

CA.name: California
CA.summary: California's Digital Financial Assets Law (DFAL) establishes a broad licensing and compliance framework for digital asset business activity. Covered entities must be licensed by, or have applied with, DFPI by July 1, 2026. For stablecoin activity, this generally acts as the main state-level baseline alongside federal requirements.
keyLaws: AB 1934 (2024) - licensure timeline extension to July 1, 2026
CA.recentDevelopments: DFPI continued DFAL rulemaking in 2025 and has already brought enforcement actions against kiosk operators under DFAL provisions.

timeline.label: DFAL enacted
timeline.detail: AB 39 and SB 401 established California's Digital Financial Assets Law framework.

timeline.label: Licensing timeline extended
timeline.detail: AB 1934 moved key licensure timing to July 1, 2026.

timeline.label: Implementation + enforcement
timeline.detail: DFPI advanced DFAL rulemaking and began enforcement actions affecting digital asset kiosks and related operations.

CA.regulatoryBody: California Department of Financial Protection and Innovation (DFPI)

WY.name: Wyoming
WY.summary: Wyoming remains one of the most crypto-forward jurisdictions in the U.S. It created a state stable token legal framework and continues operating specialized digital-asset-focused banking structures such as SPDIs. For stablecoin activity, this generally acts as the main state-level baseline alongside federal requirements.
keyLaws: Wyoming Stable Token Act (SF0127; Enrolled Act 85, 2023)
WY.recentDevelopments: Wyoming stable token administration and commission materials continue. Separate non-stablecoin policy signal: Kraken announced sponsorship of federal Trump Accounts for Wyoming newborns in 2026, citing the state's crypto policy climate.

timeline.label: SPDI charter framework established
timeline.detail: Wyoming created the SPDI charter path for qualifying digital asset banking institutions under state law.

timeline.label: Wyoming Stable Token Act enacted
timeline.detail: SF0127 established Wyoming's legal framework for a state-issued stable token program.

timeline.label: HB0264 enacted (CBDC restrictions)
timeline.detail: Wyoming enacted HB0264, reinforcing state policy limits related to central bank digital currency use.

timeline.label: Kraken Trump Accounts sponsorship announced
timeline.detail: Kraken announced it would sponsor federal Trump Accounts for Wyoming newborns in 2026 as a Wyoming crypto-policy ecosystem signal.

WY.regulatoryBody: Wyoming Division of Banking; Wyoming Stable Token Commission

TX.name: Texas
TX.summary: Texas provides explicit stablecoin treatment under its money-services framework and regulator guidance. Texas DOB guidance states that a sovereign-backed stablecoin can be treated as monetary value when reserve and redemption features are met.
keyLaws: Texas Finance Code Chapter 152 (Money Services Modernization Act / HB 1666, 2023)
Texas Finance Code Chapter 160 (digital asset service provider baseline rules)
TX.recentDevelopments: Texas maintains this stablecoin-relevant baseline and separately has SB 2922 (oil-backed stablecoin concept) pending in committee.

timeline.label: Texas stablecoin guidance issued
timeline.detail: Texas DOB guidance addressed when sovereign-backed stablecoins are treated as monetary value.

timeline.label: HB 1666 modernized money-services law
timeline.detail: Texas enacted Money Services Modernization Act provisions now codified in Chapter 152.

timeline.label: Guidance revised (Memo 1037)
timeline.detail: Texas DOB revised Supervisory Memorandum 1037 with stablecoin treatment language.

FL.name: Florida
FL.summary: Florida has a clear money-services framework that includes virtual currency transmission, creating a compliance path for stablecoin-related operations. It does not provide a blanket exemption from money transmitter licensing for stablecoin businesses.
keyLaws: Florida Statutes Chapter 560 (Money Services Businesses; includes virtual currency transmission)
FL.recentDevelopments: SB 1568 / HB 1415 (stablecoin pilot) and HB 1039 (strategic reserve) are active in the 2026 session.

timeline.label: CBDC-related UCC changes
timeline.detail: Florida enacted legislation affecting treatment of CBDCs under state law.

timeline.label: Stablecoin pilot bills filed
timeline.detail: SB 1568 and HB 1415 introduced a Florida stablecoin pilot program concept.

timeline.label: Reserve framework bill filed
timeline.detail: HB 1039 proposed a Florida strategic cryptocurrency reserve structure.

WA.name: Washington
WA.summary: Washington generally regulates digital asset businesses through its Uniform Money Services Act and related DFI policy statements. Digital asset activities commonly trigger licensing and disclosure duties under state money transmission rules. For stablecoin activity, this generally acts as the main state-level baseline alongside federal requirements.
keyLaws: Chapter 19.230 RCW - Uniform Money Services Act
DFI policy statement regarding digital asset kiosks (2024)
WA.recentDevelopments: DFI has continued active enforcement and supervision actions involving digital-asset-related operations.
WA.regulatoryBody: Washington State Department of Financial Institutions (DFI)

LA.name: Louisiana
LA.summary: Louisiana has a dedicated digital asset business activity framework administered by the Office of Financial Institutions. Entities conducting covered digital asset business activity in Louisiana generally need to follow the state's licensing regime. For stablecoin activity, this generally acts as the main state-level baseline alongside federal requirements.
LA.recentDevelopments: Louisiana OFI has continued posting annual legislative and licensing updates specific to digital asset business activity.

AZ.name: Arizona
AZ.summary: Arizona has moved on multiple digital-asset bills and enacted HB2749 in 2025 to establish a Bitcoin and digital assets reserve fund structure tied to unclaimed-property-related flows. Other reserve-focused proposals have faced vetoes, so the framework remains mixed. For stablecoin activity, this generally acts as the main state-level baseline alongside federal requirements.
keyLaws: HB2749 (2025) - Bitcoin and Digital Assets Reserve Fund
AZ.recentDevelopments: Arizona continues active digital-asset policy activity, including reserve and kiosk-related bills in recent sessions.
AZ.regulatoryBody: Arizona Department of Insurance and Financial Institutions (DIFI)

NH.name: New Hampshire
NH.summary: New Hampshire provides a meaningful exemption from money transmission licensing for persons transmitting solely convertible virtual currency. This creates a clearer operating path for certain stablecoin-related business models, while fiat-linked activities can still trigger licensure.
keyLaws: RSA 399-G:3 (money transmission exemption for solely convertible virtual currency transmission)
NH Banking Department position statement on licensing for virtual currency businesses
NH.recentDevelopments: New Hampshire continues using this exemption-based approach alongside federal baseline stablecoin rules.

NE.name: Nebraska
NE.summary: Nebraska created a digital asset bank charter path under the Nebraska Financial Innovation Act (DADI framework), providing a clearer legal route for regulated digital-asset banking activity. Nebraska officials announced charter approvals tied to stablecoin issuance capability.
keyLaws: LB649 (2021) Nebraska Financial Innovation Act (Digital Asset Depository Institution charter)
Nebraska digital-assets regulatory framework administered by NDBF
NE.recentDevelopments: State officials announced a first-in-the-nation digital asset bank charter; company disclosures reported eUSD launch under the Nebraska charter pathway.

timeline.label: Nebraska Financial Innovation Act
timeline.detail: LB649 created a state framework for digital asset depository institutions.

timeline.label: First state digital-asset bank charter announced
timeline.detail: Nebraska announced a digital-asset bank charter under its 2021 statutory framework.

NE.regulatoryBody: Nebraska Department of Banking and Finance

NJ.name: New Jersey
NJ.summary: New Jersey generally operates through existing money transmitter and broader financial-services laws without a complete stablecoin-specific framework. Companies still require model-specific licensing analysis.
NJ.recentDevelopments: Regulatory clarity remains tied to pending state proposals and the rollout of federal GENIUS Act implementation.

IL.name: Illinois
IL.summary: Illinois is modernizing its money-transmission framework through the Uniform Money Transmission Modernization Act (UMTMA), which takes effect January 1, 2026. This improves clarity for digital-asset businesses but is not a standalone stablecoin statute.
IL.recentDevelopments: IDFPR published implementation guidance for UMTMA effectiveness beginning January 1, 2026.
IL.regulatoryBody: Illinois Department of Financial and Professional Regulation (IDFPR)

PA.name: Pennsylvania
PA.summary: Pennsylvania does not currently have a full stablecoin-specific statutory framework. Most treatment remains under general money transmission and related financial regulation.
PA.recentDevelopments: No major standalone stablecoin law has been enacted.

MA.name: Massachusetts
MA.summary: Massachusetts does not have a dedicated stablecoin licensing regime and generally regulates through existing banking, money transmission, and securities authorities.
keyLaws: Money transmission and banking supervision framework
MA.recentDevelopments: Policy development remains incremental; no fully separate stablecoin statute is in force.

HI.name: Hawaii
HI.summary: Hawaii has transitioned from more restrictive approaches toward pilot and guidance-based pathways, but stablecoin-specific permanent rules remain limited.
keyLaws: Digital Currency Innovation Lab and follow-on guidance
HI.recentDevelopments: Hawaii continues post-sandbox framework discussions and remains a watch state for additional digital-asset and stablecoin-adjacent policy moves.

NV.name: Nevada
NV.summary: Nevada is generally business-friendly but does not currently have a dedicated stablecoin-specific framework.
keyLaws: State blockchain-related legislation and general financial-services regulation
NV.recentDevelopments: No major stablecoin-specific statewide framework currently in force.

UT.name: Utah
UT.summary: Utah has fintech and sandbox activity but does not currently operate a dedicated stablecoin-specific statute.
keyLaws: Utah regulatory sandbox and digital innovation initiatives
UT.recentDevelopments: State activity remains innovation-oriented, with stablecoin treatment primarily through broader financial law.

CO.name: Colorado
CO.summary: Colorado has digital-asset policy activity and public-sector crypto initiatives, but no dedicated stablecoin licensing framework.
keyLaws: State-level digital payment and blockchain initiatives
CO.recentDevelopments: Colorado continues digital-asset policy activity while stablecoin-specific requirements remain limited.

GA.name: Georgia
GA.summary: Georgia does not currently have a dedicated stablecoin framework and primarily applies general money transmission requirements.
GA.recentDevelopments: No major standalone stablecoin law is currently in force.

OH.name: Ohio
OH.summary: Ohio does not yet have a comprehensive stablecoin-specific framework, and activity is generally governed by existing financial-services and money transmission rules.
keyLaws: Money transmission and related state financial statutes
OH.recentDevelopments: Policy interest continues, but stablecoin-specific statewide treatment remains unsettled.

VT.name: Vermont
VT.summary: Vermont has adopted modified money-transmission-style treatment that includes digital asset obligations, but not a standalone stablecoin code.
keyLaws: Modified money transmission framework with digital-asset provisions
VT.recentDevelopments: The state has continued refining its implementation posture under broader financial statutes.

DE.name: Delaware
DE.summary: Delaware is blockchain-aware through corporate law modernization but has not adopted a complete stablecoin-specific financial licensing regime.
keyLaws: Delaware General Corporation Law blockchain amendments
DE.recentDevelopments: Business-law-level support continues without a bespoke stablecoin statute.

DC.name: District of Columbia
DC.summary: DC uses a money transmission framework and closely tracks federal digital asset developments. There is no independent, comprehensive stablecoin code specific to DC.
DC.recentDevelopments: Federal implementation developments are likely to drive practical compliance expectations in DC.

AK.name: Alaska
AK.summary: Alaska does not currently have a dedicated stablecoin law and primarily relies on general money-services and financial regulation.
AK.recentDevelopments: No major stablecoin-specific statutory framework is currently in force.

MI.name: Michigan
MI.summary: Michigan currently relies on existing money transmission and financial services frameworks for most digital asset activity. For stablecoin activity, this generally acts as the main state-level baseline alongside federal requirements.
MI.recentDevelopments: No comprehensive stablecoin-specific statewide regime has been enacted.

NC.name: North Carolina
NC.summary: North Carolina does not currently have a dedicated stablecoin framework; general money transmission and consumer finance rules apply.
NC.recentDevelopments: No standalone stablecoin statute is currently in force.

VA.name: Virginia
VA.summary: Virginia adopted UMTMA legislation effective July 1, 2026, modernizing money-transmission treatment for digital assets and virtual currency business activity. This is a framework modernization step rather than a dedicated stablecoin statute.
VA.recentDevelopments: Virginia SCC and legislative materials identify July 1, 2026 as the effective date for the modernized framework.
VA.regulatoryBody: Virginia State Corporation Commission (Bureau of Financial Institutions)

MD.name: Maryland
MD.summary: Maryland does not currently operate a dedicated stablecoin framework and relies on existing money transmission requirements.
MD.recentDevelopments: No standalone stablecoin law is currently in force.

OK.name: Oklahoma
OK.summary: Oklahoma currently applies general financial-services rules and money transmission obligations where applicable. For stablecoin activity, this generally acts as the main state-level baseline alongside federal requirements.
OK.recentDevelopments: No dedicated stablecoin framework has been enacted.

KY.name: Kentucky
KY.summary: Kentucky does not currently have a dedicated stablecoin licensing statute and generally relies on baseline money transmission and financial-services rules for stablecoin-related activity.
keyLaws: Kentucky money transmission and financial-services baseline requirements
KY.recentDevelopments: No major Kentucky-specific stablecoin framework has been enacted; federal stablecoin rules and existing state licensing baselines remain primary.

TN.name: Tennessee
TN.summary: Tennessee has no dedicated stablecoin licensing statute and generally relies on existing money transmission rules.
TN.recentDevelopments: No major standalone stablecoin framework has been enacted.

SC.name: South Carolina
SC.summary: South Carolina does not currently have a dedicated stablecoin statute and generally relies on standard financial services regulation.
keyLaws: General financial services and transmission oversight
SC.recentDevelopments: No major state-level stablecoin framework currently in force.

OR.name: Oregon
OR.summary: Oregon currently relies on general money transmission and financial-services regulation for most digital asset activity. For stablecoin activity, this generally acts as the main state-level baseline alongside federal requirements.
OR.recentDevelopments: No dedicated stablecoin law has been enacted.

MN.name: Minnesota
MN.summary: Minnesota does not currently have a bespoke stablecoin statute and generally uses existing money transmission regulation.
MN.recentDevelopments: No major stablecoin-specific statewide framework has been enacted.

WI.name: Wisconsin
WI.summary: Wisconsin currently applies standard financial regulation and money transmission concepts to digital asset businesses where relevant. For stablecoin activity, this generally acts as the main state-level baseline alongside federal requirements.
WI.recentDevelopments: No dedicated stablecoin licensing framework is currently in force.

IA.name: Iowa
IA.summary: Iowa does not currently have a dedicated stablecoin framework and generally governs under existing money-services rules.
IA.recentDevelopments: No major standalone stablecoin law has been enacted.

IN.name: Indiana
IN.summary: Indiana currently relies on existing money transmission and financial regulation for digital asset activity. For stablecoin activity, this generally acts as the main state-level baseline alongside federal requirements.
IN.recentDevelopments: No dedicated statewide stablecoin framework has been enacted.

MO.name: Missouri
MO.summary: Missouri does not currently have a comprehensive stablecoin statute and generally applies existing financial-services rules.
MO.recentDevelopments: No major stablecoin-specific statewide regime is currently in force.

AR.name: Arkansas
AR.summary: Arkansas does not currently have a dedicated stablecoin licensing regime and generally governs stablecoin-related activity through broader financial-services and money-transmission rules.
keyLaws: Arkansas financial-services and money transmission baseline requirements
AR.recentDevelopments: No major Arkansas-specific stablecoin framework has been enacted; federal stablecoin standards and existing state law remain the main compliance baseline.

KS.name: Kansas
KS.summary: Kansas has no dedicated stablecoin statutory regime and generally relies on existing money transmission rules.
KS.recentDevelopments: No major statewide stablecoin framework currently in force.

MS.name: Mississippi
MS.summary: Mississippi currently governs digital asset activity primarily under existing financial-services and money transmission concepts. For stablecoin activity, this generally acts as the main state-level baseline alongside federal requirements.
MS.recentDevelopments: No dedicated stablecoin licensing law has been enacted.

AL.name: Alabama
AL.summary: Alabama currently relies on existing money-services and financial licensing frameworks for digital asset activity. For stablecoin activity, this generally acts as the main state-level baseline alongside federal requirements.
keyLaws: Sale of checks / money services baseline rules
AL.recentDevelopments: No major stablecoin-specific statewide framework has been enacted.

NM.name: New Mexico
NM.summary: New Mexico does not currently have a dedicated stablecoin statute and generally uses money transmission and broader financial regulatory frameworks.
NM.recentDevelopments: No standalone stablecoin framework currently in force.

CT.name: Connecticut
CT.summary: Connecticut enacted targeted digital asset and money transmission updates with specific guardrails around virtual currency and stablecoin-related activity, creating a clearer but stricter compliance posture.
keyLaws: PA 24-146 (HB 5211) - virtual currency and money transmission amendments
PA 25-66 (HB 7082) - additional consumer-protection controls including stablecoin treatment limits in state digital payment contexts
CT.recentDevelopments: Connecticut updated statutory controls in 2024 and 2025, tightening requirements for digital-asset related activity in consumer-facing channels.

WV.name: West Virginia
WV.summary: West Virginia currently has no dedicated stablecoin statute and generally relies on existing financial regulation.
WV.recentDevelopments: No major stablecoin-specific statewide framework is currently in force.

ND.name: North Dakota
ND.summary: North Dakota does not yet have a standalone stablecoin statute, but state-linked Roughrider Coin program activity has been publicly announced through Bank of North Dakota channels.
ND.recentDevelopments: BND announced Roughrider Coin program materials and partnership updates; no separate enacted state stablecoin code is currently listed.
ND.regulatoryBody: North Dakota Department of Financial Institutions; Bank of North Dakota

SD.name: South Dakota
SD.summary: South Dakota offers trust and banking structures but does not currently have a dedicated stablecoin-specific framework.
SD.recentDevelopments: No major statewide stablecoin licensing framework currently in force.

ID.name: Idaho
ID.summary: Idaho currently relies on existing money transmission and financial-services regulation for digital asset activity. For stablecoin activity, this generally acts as the main state-level baseline alongside federal requirements.
ID.recentDevelopments: No dedicated stablecoin framework has been enacted.

ME.name: Maine
ME.summary: Maine does not currently have a dedicated stablecoin statutory framework and generally relies on broader financial-services regulation.
ME.recentDevelopments: No major standalone stablecoin framework currently in force.

RI.name: Rhode Island
RI.summary: Rhode Island currently uses standard money transmission and financial regulation for most digital asset activity. For stablecoin activity, this generally acts as the main state-level baseline alongside federal requirements.
RI.recentDevelopments: No standalone stablecoin statute has been enacted.

MT.name: Montana
MT.summary: Montana is comparatively light-touch for some digital-asset activity but does not currently have a dedicated stablecoin framework.
keyLaws: Digital asset and business-law treatment under Montana statutes
MT.recentDevelopments: No major standalone stablecoin law has been enacted.

stateIssuedStablecoins.what: Issued under Wyoming's state stable token framework by the Wyoming Stable Token Commission.
stateIssuedStablecoins.latest: Wyoming announced launch activity and continues publishing program administration materials.

stateIssuedStablecoins.what: Private stablecoin issued under Nebraska's digital-asset bank charter framework, not issued directly by the state government.
stateIssuedStablecoins.latest: Nebraska officials announced charter approval and company disclosures reported eUSD launch in December 2025.

stateIssuedStablecoins.what: Bank of North Dakota announced a state-linked stablecoin initiative targeting institutional use cases first.
stateIssuedStablecoins.latest: Program announcements and partner materials are published; rollout remains in progress.
